First, I bring them to the families. The ones with three children and one meal a day. I show them the child who used to sit listless in the dirt, eyes hollow from hunger, and now walks with purpose, carrying a small satchel and a lunch tin. That child is working—earning wages that buy rice, medicine, and a roof that doesn’t leak during the rains. That is a miracle, not a tragedy.

Then I show them the parents. The mother who can now afford to send her other child to school, not because of charity, but because her child is working. The father who no longer has to beg or lie to the local loan shark. The family that is no longer a burden on the village, but a part of its strength.

And I ask the skeptics, “Would you rather the child starve in silence, or rise with sweat and dignity?”

I speak of the village where the fields were fallow and the people were ghosts, and now the children are in the fields at dawn, planting with their fathers, learning the craft of survival. They are not cogs in a machine, they are the future of the land. They are not victims, they are contributors. They are not pitied, they are proud.

I tell them, “We do not take from the child—we give them a place in the world.”

And when the critics speak of education, I smile. I show them the children who are learning the value of a rupee, the weight of a brick, the strength of their own hands. I tell them that knowledge is not only in books—it is in the calluses on a palm, in the rhythm of labor, in the respect of elders.

Education is a luxury. Work is a birthright.

And finally, I ask them, “Would you deny a child the chance to lift their family out of despair for the sake of your conscience?”

That is how I show them the truth. Not with guilt, but with gratitude. Not with pity, but with purpose. Because in the end, what is more cruel than a world that promises dreams but offers no way to build them?
